I am trying to prove that the magnitude of a non-empty/non-zero vector (Nat List) is non-zero. I am stuck at proving an auxilary lemma with showing:

hf : autoParam (f = fun a x => a + x ^ 2) _auto✝
ih : reduce (an :: tail) i f = an ^ 2 + reduce tail i f
⊢ reduce (an :: head :: tail) i f = an ^ 2 + reduce (head :: tail) i f

Below, I tried to replace the sorry with:

have g := reduction_step_of_mags i (an::head::tail) an (head::tail) hf
exact g

But I was getting termination errors. I feel like that makes sense, because doing the above feels like "cheating".

What is the general approach in solving problems like this? Or how should I be thinking about this problem / why would the above not be correct?

Edit: Made a post below with my response/solution

Original code missing necessary assumption

def reduce (v: List Nat) (n: A) (f: A → Nat → A): A :=
  match v with
  | [] => n
  | vn::vs => reduce vs (f n vn) f

def mag2 (v: List Nat): Nat := reduce v 0 (λ a x => a + (x ^ 2))

theorem consed_not_eq_zero (a: List Nat) (h: a = an::as): a.length ≠ 0 := by
  have z := List.length_cons an as
  have hz := Nat.add_one_ne_zero as.length
  replace hz := (h ▸ z) ▸ hz
  exact hz

theorem reduction_step_of_mags (i: Nat) (a: List Nat) (an: Nat) (as: List Nat)
    (hf: f = λ a x => a + x ^ 2 := by rfl):
    reduce (an::as) i f = an ^ 2 + reduce as i f := by
  have hfr: f i an = an ^ 2 + i := by
    rw [hf]
    conv => right; apply Nat.add_comm

  induction as
  . simp [reduce]
    rw [hfr]
  . rename_i head tail ih
    sorry

theorem mag2_not_zero (v: List Nat) (p: ∀ x ∈ v, x ≠ 0) (q: v.length ≠ 0): mag2 v ≠ 0 :=
  match h: v with
  | [] => by
    rw [List.length_nil] at q
    contradiction
  | vn::vs => by
    have hNotZero: vn ≠ 0 := p vn (List.mem_cons_self vn vs)

    have hSplit: mag2 v = vn ^ 2 + mag2 vs := by
      simp [mag2]
      have g := reduction_step_of_mags 0 v vn vs
      replace g := h ▸ g
      exact g

    have hgz := Nat.pos_of_ne_zero hNotZero
    have h2gz: vn ^ 2 > 0 := Nat.pow_pos hgz
    have h0: 0 < vn ^ 2 + mag2 vs := Nat.add_pos_left h2gz (mag2 vs)
    rw [←hSplit] at h0

    rw [h] at h0
    rw [Nat.ne_zero_iff_zero_lt]
    exact h0

I am really struggling with proofs and Lean in general, but usually after staring at a problem long enough and searching online, I could eventually find a solution. With this problem, I feel like I am just missing something in regards to recursion and induction; although, I feel proud that I got this far (with the help of the community and AI).
Okay, I think I found the mistake, I was missing the assumption/argument: (h: a = an::as). Silly. I'll try to work on this myself a bit more

Thanks for this, that actually helped more than I expected. I assumed it was such a small and simple function that it wouldn't really make a difference if I used my own version but it did. I was able to solve this problem because I found this when I searched for foldl here on the zulip chat: #new members > ✔ Proof strategies for foldl?

For anybody else new to Lean (who isn't already really strong in math/proofs/problem solving) runs into an issue like this, here are some things that can help:

  • Reading the "Theorem Proving in Lean" book (especially 7/8 on induction and recursion)
  • Building out a proof as much as you can, breaking down a large problem into subproblems/lemmas that you can fill with "sorry" as you continue building the rest of the proof
  • Using standard definitions and theorems as much as possible, since they might come accompanied with other supporting lemmas or definitions that could assist. But also, since it's easier to search for similar problems using standard/common functions
  • Trying to focus on implementing the proof in your head with Lean. Sometimes I'll have an idea of something I want to do but don't know how to do it, so I end up looking for a different route to solve the problem. But it's probably better just figuring out how to express your idea in Lean since you might have already "proved" it in your head / on paper

There was a point where I had an induction hypothesis and goal like:

ih : List.foldl f i xs = i + List.foldl f 0 xs
⊢ List.foldl f (f i x) xs = i + List.foldl f (f 0 x) xs

and noticed that if I could use the induction hypothesis as a function over i I could just insert in (f i x) for i and that could help solve the goal. But I thought it was impossible or I was supposed to solve it another way for some reason. Later I found the induction induction a generalizing i tactic which did exactly what I wanted. It was able to transform the ih to:

ih : ∀ (i : Nat), List.foldl f i xs = i + List.foldl f 0 xs

And boom, problem solved

Solution

def mag2 (v: List Nat): Nat := v.foldl (λ a x => a + (x ^ 2)) 0

theorem mags2_apply (i: Nat) (h: Nat) (hf: f = λ a x => a + x ^ 2 := by rfl): f i h = i + h ^ 2 := by
  rw [hf]

theorem foldl_mags2_init (i: Nat) (a: List Nat) (hf: f = λ a x => a + x ^ 2 := by rfl):
    a.foldl f i = i + a.foldl f 0 := by
  induction a generalizing i
  case nil => rfl
  case cons x xs ih =>
    simp [List.foldl]
    have lhs := ih (f i x)
    have rhs := ih (f 0 x)
    rw [lhs, rhs]
    rw [hf]
    simp_arith

theorem foldl_mags2_cons (i: Nat) (an: Nat) (as: List Nat) (hf: f = λ a x => a + x ^ 2 := by rfl):
    (an::as).foldl f i = (as.foldl f i) + an ^ 2 := by
  simp
  induction as
  . simp
    rw [hf]
  . rename_i h t _ih
    simp [List.foldl_cons]
    rw [mags2_apply i an hf]
    rw [mags2_apply (i + an^2) h hf]
    rw [mags2_apply i h hf]
    rw [foldl_mags2_init (i + an ^ 2 + h ^ 2) t hf]
    rw [foldl_mags2_init (i + h ^ 2) t hf]
    simp_arith

theorem mag2_not_zero (v: List Nat) (p: ∀ x ∈ v, x ≠ 0) (q: v.length ≠ 0): mag2 v ≠ 0 :=
  match h: v with
  | [] => by
    rw [List.length_nil] at q
    contradiction
  | vn::vs => by
    have hNotZero: vn ≠ 0 := p vn (List.mem_cons_self vn vs)

    have hSplit: mag2 v = mag2 vs + vn ^ 2 := by
      simp [mag2]
      have g := foldl_mags2_cons 0 vn vs
      rw [h]
      exact g

    have hgz := Nat.pos_of_ne_zero hNotZero
    have h2gz: vn ^ 2 > 0 := Nat.pow_pos hgz
    have h0: 0 < mag2 vs + vn ^ 2 := Nat.add_pos_right (mag2 vs) h2gz
    rw [←hSplit] at h0

    rw [h] at h0
    rw [Nat.ne_zero_iff_zero_lt]
    exact h0
